Joe pretty much has it.  Just to add to that, it used to be that 
people who designed topology-evolving algorithms would usually 
support their use by explaining that they find the "optimal 
topology" for the problem, i.e. at the *end* of evolution, you have 
a really good solution.

My point was that the goal is not just to "end up" with something 
good, but to have something good (meaning small) the whole way 
through, so that you actually get an advantage in the *search*, not 
just in the final topology.  In fact, for a lot of problems, it's 
the search itself that is the problem, and the final topology 
doesn't even matter that much.  (Of course, NEAT tends to find 
minimal solutions as well, so it's final solutions have that nice 
property, but that's not the main point.)

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@c...> wrote:
> Hi German,
> 
> I'll go ahead and field this one, and let Ken add any comments if 
need be.
> 
> > My question is what does the text mean by "rather than only at 
the very
> > end"?
> 
> A really common problem in Neuro-evolution (and in complexifying 
genetic
> algorithms as a whole) is that genetic structure is sometimes 
added that
> doesn't serve any purpose. This kind of structure can accrue over 
time and
> make the chromosome sizes very large (which increases the number of
> dimensions in the search space). To make the evolved networks more
> understandable/computationally efficient, some systems simplify 
the output
> of overly complex genetic code at the "end" of evolution. For 
example, if
> neuron A is connected to neuron B by link 1 and also link 2, then 
the
> weights of these two links are summed and the connection is 
simplified to
> one link. This "simplifies" the neural network but doesn't result 
in a
> loss in functionality.
> 
> Ken's hypothesis was that if we could somehow avoid adding this 
kind of
> redundant structure in the first place, then the GA search takes 
place
> over a smaller space, and therefore can be more efficient.
> 
> Hope that helps.
> 
> Joe
> 
> -- 
> 
> Joseph Reisinger
> http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/joeraii
